body: @kayousterhout @mridulm addressed the concurrency issue in Accumulator, handle speculative case in DAGScheduler (identify the speculative task by checking if there is an earlier task ran on the same partition)

All automated tests passed.

Will this cause some problem in EC2, where the bindHost is usually the private IP?

if the JettyServer is started with the private IP address, the user cannot access through Internet....

(I didn't test)

I don't think this would cause any problems. The user can override both the internal and external ip's using SPARK_LOCAL_IP and SPARK_PUBLIC_DNS. This patch makes sure the right value is used in the right circumstance.

thanks @liancheng , @marmbrus 

I've update some of the code style.

I took a very high level pass at this and here are some high-level things that must be fixed. 
1. Follow to Spark formatting style, refer to https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/SPARK/Spark+Code+Style+Guide . You can use the Spark in-built style checker using 'sbt/sbt scalastyle'
2. Real unit tests, see in-code comments
3. More documentation, both Java docs and as well as in-code documentation. 
4. Please add a [JIRA ticket](https://spark-project.atlassian.net/secure/Dashboard.jspa) for this and update the PR subject accordingly (see other PRs).
5. Directory name should be short and lowercase, consistent with rest of the external projects.
Thanks I've merged this - we'll see how it goes.
Looks good to me. Thanks TD!

Can one of the admins verify this patch?

We're using the shaded version from Kryo. If they change this in future releases we can change accordingly, but other projects are also using Kryo's shaded version so I don't think it's something they are likely to change.
@tdas is this up to date? seems like it still includes the bounded map and some other things related to older versions of the patch
Looks good to me. One small style comment.
Also, refer to the discussion here https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/100 This PR only backports the changes already accepted in master.

@tdas IMO a large change to the DAGScheduler is a little scary to merge into a patch release. DAG scheduler + akka actor semantics is even scarier! It might be worth letting this sit in master for a while in case we find bugs, then back porting it into 0.9.2 if we find it stable.
I was keeping the BoundedHashMap around in case the broadcast stuff needs it. I will remove that in case its not necessary. Other than that the changes are pretty much done. You can review it.

Hey thanks for looking at this. //cc @ahirreddy who ran into this today also. I'm wondering though, is the real bug here that `createClassLoader` doesn't properly set the parent of the created `ExecutorURLClassLoader`?

If the class `Foo` is correctly visible to the Executor with the changes you propose here, then I wonder if the delegation order is just messed up. In theory the `replClassLoader` should not try to load the class if it's already visible from a parent.

Ya okay I think my suspicion was correct. I made the following modification to `createClassLoader` and I was able to fix this bug:

```
private def createClassLoader(): ExecutorURLClassLoader = {
-    val loader = this.getClass.getClassLoader
+    val loader = Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader
```

The problem is that it delegated to the classloader which created the current class. Instead it should delegate to the classloader that is currently active in the present thread.

Nice catch actually that is the reason. I think we should also include the fix proposed in this patch along with yours.

I look at it differently, Patrick.  Our current handling of exceptions thrown within the DAGScheduler is already completely broken -- luckily, they're fairly rare.  If we screw up the attempt to handle them better, we don't end up any more completely broken.  If we get it at least partially right, we're in better shape.

I actually don't think this change will be that invasive, and it fixes an
annoying issue (that is a regression in 0.9) so I think it should go into
the 0.9 branch, but given timing I don't think 0.9.1 makes sense (since
there isn't even a patch for this yet!).

Thanks for the proposals everyone. For our case a Spark-enforced timeout might not be ideal, and only moving `listenerBus.stop()` to the end of `sc.stop()` probably does not guarantee draining. So how about exposing a binary flag from `SparkContext`, plus moving `listenerBus.stop()`? To recap, this makes sure other states / info get cleaned up in `sc.stop()` and do not get stuck because of the listener bus, and the user application can have the flexibility to poll the binary drained flag.

Hey @concretevitamin sorry I think our proposal was the following:
1. Modify the listenerbus.stop() method to wait until all events are empty.
2. Call listenerbus.stop() in sc.stop()

This doesn't change anything visible to the user.
@yinxusen It looks good to me now. @rxin , could you please make a final scan and merge it if it looks good to you? Thanks!

Thank you for your reply.

In my opinion, there are 2 problems:
1. One of the ContextClassLoaders of `LocalActor`'s threads is tainted in the constructor of `Executor`.
2. The delegation order is messed up.

The first is fixed by my patch, and the second is fixed by @pwendell's patch.

I have added the @pwendell's patch and pushed.
